variant.question: A steady green light from aerodrome control tower directed towards an aircraft on ground means

options.text: taxi back to the starting point on the aerodrome (return back to the parking stand).
cleared to enter the runway and wait for takeoff clearance signal.

variant.question: What shall be the minimum length of a row of lights on the extended centre line of a simple approach lighting system whenever possible?
What is a "precision approach"? It is a direct instrument approach:

options.text: Which uses azimuth, elevation and distance information.
Which uses bearing, elevation and distance information, providing the pilot uses a flight director or an autopilot certified to a height below 200 ft.
Which is carried out by a crew of at least two pilots trained with a specific working method.
Which uses at least one source of bearing information and one source of elevation or distance information.

variant.question: Which route designator is used on charts to show that the route is primarily used by helicopters?
The light shown by an 'Aerodrome Identification Beacon' at a land aerodrome shall be

options.text: Green colour identification given by Morse Code.
Blue colour identification given by Morse Code.
White and green colour identification given by Morse Code.
White colour identification given by Morse Code.

variant.question: How many red lights must a pilot see, whose aircraft, in final approach, is following a normal glide path defined by a PAPI?

A pilot making an approach sees 3 white lights and 1 red light on the wingbar of a PAPI. This means that he/she:

options.text: is on the prescribed glide slope.
is on the centre line axis.

variant.question: Airport signs shall be illuminated when intended for use:

options.text: In runway visual range conditions less than 1 000 m.
At night, on non-precision approach runways only.

variant.question:
Refer to figure. 
 Which option below has the correct order to fit the PAPIs showing?

options.text: (I.) Above the approach slope; (II.) on or close to the approach slope.
(I.) Above the approach slope; (II.) below the approach slope.
(I.) On or close to the approach slope; (II.) below the approach slope.
(I.) Below the approach slope; (II.) on or close to the approach slope.

variant.question: What PAPI lights will the pilot see when the aircraft is well above the approach slope?

options.text: All four units are steady white.
All four units are flashing white.
The unit nearest to and the unit farthest from the runway are white, the two others are red.
The unit nearest to and the unit farthest from the runway are steady white, the two in the centre are flashing white.

variant.question: The 'PAPI' shall consist of

options.text: a wing bar of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.
a wing bar of 2 sharp transition multi-lamp equally spaced.
two wing bars of 6 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.
two wing bars of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp or paired units equally spaced.

 Runway centreline lights shall be fixed lights showing variable (1)___ from the threshold to the point 900 m from the runway end, alternate (2)___ and variable (3)___ from 900 m to 300 m from runway end, and (4)___ from 300 m to the runway end.
Runway threshold lights shall be:

options.text: Fixed unidirectional lights showing red in the direction of the runway.
Fixed unidirectional lights showing white in the direction of the runway.

options.text: pilot will oversteer and the cockpit will NOT follow the centre-line markings.

Runway edge lights except in the case of a displaced threshold shall be:

options.text: Fixed lights showing variable white or yellow.
Fixed lights, white or yellow color.

variant.question: To cross lighted stop bars on the manoeuvring area of an aerodrome, the following applies:

options.text: an aircraft may only proceed further if the lights are switched off.
lighted stop bars may only be crossed with the authorization of the aerodrome control tower.
an aircraft shall stop and hold at all lighted stop bars unless otherwise authorized by the aerodrome control tower.
an aircraft has to stop and hold at all lighted stop bars if so required by the aerodrome control tower.

variant.question: When a threshold is displaced, what colour shall the lights have in approach direction between the beginning of the runway and the displaced threshold?

options.text: Blue, this portion of the runway is considered as taxyway.
Flashing red, intermittent with flashing white.

variant.question: The colour of fixed, unidirectional Runway End Lights shall be:
In the "PAPI" system the pilot during an approach will see the two units nearest the runway as red and the two units farthest from the runway as white when:

options.text: on or close to the approach slope.

variant.question: When shall a runway be equipped with boundary lights (runway edge lights)?

options.text: When the runway is intended for use at night.
When the runway and its surroundings are indistinguishable.
When the runway is NOT equipped with centreline lights.
When the runway length is less than 300 m.

variant.question: Runway centreline lights shall be fixed lights showing variable ___ from the threshold to the point 900 m from the runway end, alternate ___ and variable ___ from 900 m to 300 m from runway end, and ___ from 300 m to the runway end.
Which of the following systems describes an abbreviated precision approach path indicator?

options.text: A wing bar of 2 sharp transition multi-lamp units normally located on the left side of the runway unless it is physically impracticable to do so.
Ten light units arranged on one side of the runway in the form of a single wing bar of four light units, with a bisecting longitudinal line of six lights.
A wing bar of 4 sharp transition multi-lamp units equally spaced and normally located on the left side of the runway unless it is physically impracticable to do so.
Twenty light units symmetrically disposed about the runway centre line in the form of two wing bars of four light units each, with bisecting longitudinal lines of six lights.

variant.question: A precision Category I lighting system shall consist of a row of lights on the extended runway centre line over a distance...

300 m with a row of lights forming a crossbar 30 m in length at a distance of 150 m from the runway threshold.
1 200 m with a row of lights forming a crossbar 30 m in length at a distance of 420 m from the runway threshold.
600 m with a row of lights forming a crossbar 30 m in length at a distance of 300 m from the runway threshold.

variant.question: When on or close to the approach slope, the wing bar of a PAPI shows:

options.text: two red lights and two white lights.
three white lights and one red light.

variant.question: Runway edge lights are

options.text: fixed variable intensity unidirectional showing white or yellow.
fixed variable intensity unidirectional showing green.
fixed variable intensity unidirectional showing blue.
fixed variable intensity unidirectional showing red.

A length of at least 150 m and a distance of 30 m between the crossbars.

A length of at least 600 m and a distance of 100 m between the crossbars.

two parallel rows of lights leading towards the runway.
a group of at least 5 flashing yellow lights.
an arbitrary amount of green lights.

options.text: taxiing need not be confined to the taxiways.
glider flying is performed outside the landing area.
this aerodrome is using parallel runways.
landing, take-off and taxiing is allowed on runway and/or taxiway only.

At night an aircraft observes a luminous signal requesting help. To indicate that he has received these search and rescue ground signals, the pilot shall:

options.text: switch his landing lights on and off twice or, if he/she is not so equipped, his/her navigation lights twice.
make at least one complete turn over the group of people in difficulty.
fly over the group of people in difficulty as low as possible.
transmit, by luminous Morse signal, a series of the letter "R" using his navigational lights.
